div.p: 1. IV.30. Walk of an hour instead of the bath in the river.
symbols David symbols 8. David smites Moab and Syrians.
Southard. S.N. brought several papers relating to affairs of the Treasury. Mr Rush this day received his Commission as Secretary of the Treasury, and entered upon the duties of the Department.

Brent— Daniel had a Letter from Mr Bangeman Huygens, commissioned as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from the Netherlands, announcing his arrival at New-York; to be here about the middle of this month.

list.head: Dutcher said he expected to pass next winter here.

div.p: Jones— Coll. brought me a Letter from T. P. Andrews to Genl Brown dated Milledgeville 20. July. Affairs of Creek Indians and Georgia—

Brown Genl. concerning the Indian chief charged with murder in Michigan Territory, whether to be delivered up to the civil authority for trial? As Schoolcraft the Indian Agent released him; it is expedient to wait a few days that the report from Schoolcraft may be received at the War Department—

Brown spoke also of Andrews’s Letter, and Genl. Gaines’s, to Govr. Troup. Also of Porter’s trial; and Mr Monroe’s answers to the interrogatories—and of Genl. La Fayette to whom the Genl. gives a party to-morrow Evening— He had invited me and Mrs Adams and my family; but I declined for myself following the example of all my predecessors, none of whom ever attended at private parties.
Page C. C. the young man from Vermont came again, to apply for a midshipman’s warrant: I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy to whom I had spoken in his behalf

My Son John went out to Ross’s to meet Genl La Fayette and they arrived here between 4 and 5. O’Clock P.M. the General was accompanied by Coll. Howard and Coll. Randall
members of a Baltimore Committee of Arrangements.
Mr George Washington La Fayette and Mr Le Vasseur came in the stage, which the General and his two companions from Baltimore had quitted— They arrived about half an hour after the General.

Just before dinner Mr William J. Redd from Missouri, came and delivered to me Letters of Introduction from T. H. Benton, and W. Clark— He was desirous of seeing Genl La Fayette, who I told him would readily see him to-morrow Morning.

Mr Southard, Genl. Brown, and Judge Hay, were here in the Evening— Mr Southard invited the General to dine with him on Thursday; and invited me also; which I declined on the same principle as I had the invitation of Genl. Brown.
2. V:30 symbols 9. Mephibosheth and Ziba 10. Hanum—Ammonite war
Gardner a Clerk formerly dismissed from the Land-Office applies to be re-instated.
Rush— R. Secretary of the Treasury—called on a morning visit.

I went with Genl. La Fayette, Mr Southard, Captain Morris. G W La Fayette and Le Vasseur to the Navy-Yard and visited the frigate Brandywine, which is preparing for sea— We went on board the ship, and examined every part of her— A Salute was fired from the Shore on our boarding the ship, and the Marine Corps with their band of music were paraded at the gate of the Navy Yard, and on the wharf at the side of which the ship was lying— The ship is to be moved down below the Bar to-morrow— We returned at half past twelve, and from one to three the General received visits—
Bomford— Coll. brought me several drawings of Eagles, for the Pediment of the Capitol—which he thought improvements on the design of Persico

list.head: Bache is the Postmaster at Philadelphia—a visit— He is to return to-morrow home.

div.p: Barbour— J. S— detained on business, but thinks of going to-morrow.
Degrand. P. P. F. proposes going to-morrow, but doubtful.

Company to dine— Messrs.Barron, Biddle, Brown (Captain)Coxe, Downes, Elliott, Hay, Henley, Hopkinson, Johnston, Jones (Jacob)Jones (Walter)M’Intyre, M’Lean, Morris, Read, Redd, Renshaw, Ridgely, Rodgers, Rush, Seaton, Southard, Spence, Thompson, Tingey, Weightman, Wirt—with Genl. La Fayette, his Son, and Mr Le Vasseur— They went in the Evening to a party at Genl. Browns— Mary and Elizabeth and my Son Charles went with them. John was unwell, and did not go.
3. V. Precisely at Sun rise.

list.item: symbols 11. Bathsheba. 12. Nathan’s symbols 13. Amnon & Tamar

M’Duel, John— His mother has a pension from the British Government—proposes to send a power to T. Aspinwall our Consul at London, and asks for a Letter to him— I referred him to D. Brent, at the Department of State.
G. W. La Fayette left us to visit Coll. Lewis at Wood-lawn
Genl La Fayette introduced to me a Swiss purchaser of lands in Virginia and Kentucky— Also Huger, late a Cadet at West-Point son of his old Liberator; and now employed in the Engineer Department.
Watkins Dr. brought a Letter from Eb. Herrick about the Office of Collector at Bath, Maine, Mark L. Hill, Governor Parris and Mr Swanton.
Hunter— Coll. of Georgia desires me to examine all the papers relating to his claim for negroes in the Creek Nation, which I promised him I would do.
Page. C. C. the Vermont boy—brought a Letter from his father who is very anxious that he should obtain the Midshipman’s warrant— I advised him to shew it to Mr Southard
Syon— Mr de, introduced by General La Fayette

list.head: They are both of Counsel for Captain Stewart

list.item: Graham— George— with his Son, a Cadet at West-Point.

div.p: Company to dine— Messrs.J. S. Barbour, Bomford, D. Brent, R. Cutts, Degrand, C. W. Goldsborough, Hagner, Coll. Henderson, Benjn. Huger, Coll. Hunter, J. H. Johnston, Coll. R. Jones, Captn. Kuhn, W. Lee, Dr Lovell, Genl Macomb, Genl Mason, S Pleasonton, T. Ringgold, Coll. Roberdeau, de Syon—Dr Thornton, Coll. Towson, Major Van de Venter and Dr Watkins—with Genl. La Fayette and Mr Le Vasseur.
4. V:15. Walk to the river instead of my morning bath.
symbols 14. Widow of Tekoah 15. Absalom’s rebellion 16. Shimei’s curse.
Wright— Mr. for Mrs Bell, widow of the Stage-driver that was killed
Grant Mrs a widow from Virginia; going to the State of New-York
Southard— S.N. with list of Stores to be provided for the Brandywine remarks upon them—
Peter— Thomas, a visit intended for Genl. La Fayette

list.head: returned from the Survey of the roads to New-Orleans

div.p: Shriver and Dutton had left their cards

Watkins Dr. with a Letter from Thurlow Weed—wants the printing of the Laws for the Rochester Telegraph—and speaks of Mr Southard as very unpopular— Watkins had also a Letter of solicitation from L. D. Teackle, and verbal solicitations of influence in behalf of Dr Thornton—
General La Fayette, and his family, and my Son John dined at Mr Southard’s— G. W. La Fayette returned from Woodlawn symbols
5. V:15. Sixteen years since I embarked for Russia.

list.item: An hour’s walk to the river, instead of the bath
symbols 17. Ahithophel’s death 18. Absalom’s. 19. David’s restoration 20 Shebal rebellion.

div.p: Mr. Anderson came to make enquiries, concerning the Law School of Messrs.Mills and Howe at Northampton, Massachusetts, and also to state a question upon the construction of revenue Law— I mentioned to him the Letter from Cummings & Hilliard about the duty upon Books
Foster had several Letters of recommendation in favour of Jas H. Bennett in relation to his quarrel with Kirkpatrick—he left the Letters with me.
Elliott’s object was to remonstrate against the transfer of the astronomical instruments from the War Department to West Point, which was proposed by the board of visitors.

Dr Thornton left with me a Letter from F. A. Browne to Mr Clay with a written opinion of J. Sergeant and H. Binney, that all persons have a right to demand copies of Patents and specifications, and a reply by the Dr— He spoke also of my remark, to Dr. Watkins upon Thornton’s altercation last Winter with Genl. Houston.

Mr Graham has just returned from his excursion with his new married wife. He brought the Patent of the grant of a Township of Land to Genl. La Fayette in Florida, under an Act of Congress at their last Session, which I signed; with another explanatory of a former grant to him near the City of New-Orleans— I signed also ten Grants on Virginia Military warrants—and three ordinary Land-grants at Chilicothe, and Zanesville—Ohio and Kaskaskia—Illinois—in all 15
Mr Brent came with Mr Pearson and Mr Gaston, as visitors—
Mr Gaston has just arrived from North-Carolina.

Mrs Wonderley stated that she had married a man at New York, who had brought her here, and then left her and gone off—after which she had discovered that he was already married to another woman. She wanted assistance to return home to her friends.

Major Van de Venter brought some papers relating to the claim of Mr Hunter, of Georgia, for negroes born in the Creek Nation— He afterwards at my request sent me from the War Department the volume containing the Instructions to Govr Preston, and the Letters from the Secretary of War to the Govr. of Georgia, on this subject.

Wingate and Burleigh, just arrived from Maine, came with reference to the appointment of a Collector for the Port of Bath on the place of Mark Langdon Hill, who it is taken for granted will be removed or resign— The reports of the Commissioners appointed to investigate the charges against him, has been received yesterday at the Treasury Department, and I received this morning an explanatory Memorial with sundry Documents from Hill— Burleigh and Wingate brought a volume of recommendations for Swanton who has been many years the deputy Collector at Bath, and I received two Letters from the Governor of Maine Albion K. Parris, presenting himself as a Candidate, for the appointment—one of these was given me by the Comptroller Anderson, who had also Letters from Judge Whitman and Judge Ware two of the Commissioners of investigation upon Hill—the Letters were addressed to me but Anderson was enjoined to deliver them only in case of the resignation or removal of Hill—while at the request of Parris he informed me that the purport of their contents was to recommend him as Collector at Bath
Many of the Letters brought by Wingate and Burleigh most vehemently remonstrate against the appointment of Parris, and it has apparently become an exceedingly exasperated party question in the State.

Rush— Richard— Secy Treasury— had not yet read through the report of the Commissioners in the case of M. L. Hill— I gave him Hill’s memorial to me; and he will examine and report to me upon the whole matter

Mr Rush mentioned several other subjects relating to the administration of the Treasury Department, and Mr Southard several, concerning that of the Navy— Among which was the substitution of three Captains in the place of Biddle, Downes, and Ridgely, for the trial of Captain Stewart— I thought the change ought to be made— I remarked to Mr Southard the difference in the indications of public sentiment, upon the trials of Porter and of Stewart— And he said that here, all the apparent show in Porter’s favour was made by the partizans of Mr Crawford— I noticed to him the singular inconsistency between Mr Hayne’s Letter to him in relation to Porter, and the malignant attacks of the Charleston Mercury, known to be under Haynes controul and edited by his wife’sbrother.

We had company to dine. Mr and Mrs Southard, Mr Rush, Genl. and Mrs Brown, Mr and Mrs Frye, Mr and Mrs W. S Smith, George Graham, Genl. Taylor, Mr Hopkinson and his Son Alexander, Genl. Bernard and Captain Poussin; with Genl. La Fayette and his family— Mr and Mrs Wirt, Mrs Rush, Mr. Shriver, and Messrs. Burleigh and Wingate were invited but did not come.
Mrs Rush and her family arrived yesterday.
Genl. La Fayette, his family and our young Ladies attended an evening party at Genl. Mason’s
6. V:30— Walked an hour—

Smith came to express his grateful acknowledgments upon receiving the appointment of a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps— Mr. Erwin is the Son in Law of Mr Clay, and left him with his family at Lebanon, in the State of Ohio, the 25th. of last Month. Brought me a Letter of that date from Mr Clay— His daughter was yet dangerously ill and he knew not when he should be able to proceed on his journey— Mr Dydenhoven, and Mr
Ridgate were applicants for Offices. Coll. Roberdeau came to take leave—going with his daughters Mary and Susan to the Bedford Springs.

We dined at 2. O’Clock—Mr Erwin, and Mr Tench Ringgold the Marshal of the District, dined with us— At 4—General La Fayette, his Son G. W. Mr Ringgold and I, departed, on a visit to Mr Monroe at Oakhill— My Son John and Mr Le Vasseur went with us— And the General’s Valet de Chambre Bastien and Antoine Michel Giusta, in a Carry all with one horse took the baggage— William the Groom followed us on horseback. We crossed the Potowmack Bridge, and rode 16 Miles to Fairfax Court-house. Arrived there just after Sunset, at 7 in the Evening and lodged at Bronaugh’s Hotel— Several of the Residents in the Neighbourhood came to pay their respects to General La-Fayette

7. IV:30. Soon after five we left Fairfax Court-house, where I had found a very tolerable lodging, and rode seven Miles to a Mr Mitchell’s, where we breakfasted—not a regular tavern. Mitchell was an old man, who had been in the war of the Revolution, and is now a lame invalide— Continuing our road about six Miles before reaching Mr Monroe’s, one of the cross pieces of wood over the fore axel tree of our Carriage and upon which one of the Springs of the Carriage rested, snapped short off. Mr G. W. La Fayette and Mr Ringgold then left the Carriage to the General and me, after splicing the wounded cross-piece, as it could be done at the moment, and they went on alternately walking, and riding in my Son’s tandem gig, changeably with John and Le Vasseur. About 3 miles short of Mr Monroe’s house we met Mr George Hay taking a morning ride on horseback to meet us— We got to Mr Monroe’s house, just before noon: and our fellow travellers joined us there about an hour later. We found Mr Monroe in good health and Spirits— Mrs Hay and her daughter
daughter Hortensia were there; but Mrs Monroe is at New-York with her daughter Mrs Gouverneur— We found there also Doctor Wallace an eccentric personage, who spent great part of last Winter at Washington with Mr Monroe, and had now just arrived here upon a visit— There was also a Mr Noland heretofore a neighbour of Mr Monroe’s—lately removed to the Arkansas Territory, and receiver of Public monies at Batesville— There were several other visitors in the course of the day whose names escape my recollection. There was a heavy thunder shower, about the dining hour, and the Evening was fresh and cool— It was questionable whether the Carriage could be adequately repaired at the neighbouring village of Aldie, and to provide for the more than probable contingency of other and graver accidents I was desirous of sending off the groom William, to Washington, this Evening, to order my old coachman Joseph Abbott to come here, with his Hack. He would arrive on Tuesday Morning in Season to bear us company the remainder of our way— But my son John persuaded me to give up this purpose

8. V. The night was cool, and this morning fresh; but I was all this day unwell— The heat of the Season returned in all it force so that we were confined almost entirely to the house. Numerous visitors came in the course of the day— Mrs Noland—her Son in Law and daughter Berkeley—Mrs Armistead, Ludwell Lee and his Son Richard Henry Lee—who remained at dinner. Genl. La Fayette, has had an invitation from Leesburg since soon after his arrival in this Country, and goes there to-morrow— He is invited also to lodge at Mr Ludwell Lee’s to-morrow night— Mr Lee gave me an invitation there also which I accepted. His son left on going away a Letter for me, explaining two Letters which he had written me last Winter— The names of several of the visitors this day were not mentioned to me; or not remembered by me— The day was spent in desultory Conversations, with Mr Monroe, Mr Hay, Genl. La Fayette, Dr. Wallace, Mrs Hay, and the visitors at
the house— Dr Wallace engrossed much of the conversation; and was much gratified by the appearance on the porch of the house of a small Mocassin Snake, which he caught, and descanted upon for perhaps an hour, shewing us all its beauties, and especially the venom bag under its forked tongue— He told me he was just recovering from a dropsy brought on by his swallowing the whole contents of a Rattlesnake’s venom bag— The Doctor is extremely solicitous to go out in the Brandywine as an extra-Surgeon.

9. V. Perhaps the hottest day of the Season— Between 9 and 10 this Morning two Troops of Horse, arrived at Mr Monroe’s from Leesburg to escort General La Fayette thither— They brought also a Carriage, in which, with Mr Monroe and Mr Henderson one of the Committee of Arrangements I accompanied the General— His Son, Mr Le Vasseur, Mr Hay, Mr Ringgold, my Son and Dr Wallace followed in other Carriages— In about two hours we came to a field, just at the entrance of Leesburg where several Militia Companies were drawn up which were reviewed. Thence we proceeded to a public House, where the General was addressed by the Mayor—Dr M’Cabe; and after numerous introductions of persons of both sexes, we proceeded to the Town Hall in the Yard of which the General was addressed by a boy of about twelve years old—then by a few lines of verses by a little girl of 5 or 6 and finally under the porch of the Hall by Mr Ludwell Lee, for the County— The General answered them all— We went back to the Public House, where new introductions were undergone and about five O’Clock repaired to a Public dinner under a Canopy in the Court House-yard— There might be at this dinner about a hundred persons— There was toasting to the General; to the late and present Presidents and many others— We left the table about Sunset; and went to a Mr Mason’s, where two children were baptised, one named Mary La Fayette, to which the General stood Sponsor, and the other Maria Louisa; for whom at the request of the Parents, Mr Monroe and
myself were Sponsors—the Parents of the children are relations of Dr Wallace, who was there; and I believe much concerned in the management of the affair— We then after stopping again at the Public House to join our companions left Leesburg, and about nine in the Evening reached Mr Ludwell Lee’s house, five miles from Leesburg— The escort from Leesburg left us and returned home; leaving still a numerous company as guests to Mr Lee— A chamber with two beds, was allotted to Mr. Monroe and me— We found at Mr Lee’s several Ladies of his family, and Mrs Catlett of Alexandria, as a visitor— A full account of this day’s proceedings will be published in the Newspapers— I have no pleasure in such Scenes.

10. V. The night was oppressively hot; and this day still more so. The General was detained, in writing for the press his answers to the Addresses of yesterday, and his toasts, so that it was between nine and ten, when we took leave of Mr Ludwell Lee, and of Mr Monroe, who returned home to Oak-hill— We had a blazing and suffocating day; and a choice of roads most unfit to be travelled, by light Carriages and pampered horses. We stopped for an hour after riding about eight miles— Then proceed about a mile, on an old road which had been recommended, as not so bad as the others; but upon which we found we could scarcely fail of oversetting if we proceeded— We returned and took the Turnpike road, hilly and excessively rough nine miles to Drane’s— On ascending the hill called the bull’s neck, within a hundred yards of the house; the most spirited of my four horses fell, never again to rise— He was bled in the neck and leg, but died in about three quarters of an hour— We had sent word this morning to Mrs Adams to expect us home to dinner, at 5. O’Clock, which this accident rendered impossible. We stopped to dine, and give rest to the surviving horses, at the Inn. Sending on the groom William, on horseback, with notice to Mrs Adams not to expect us till the Evening; and with a direction to send a Hack to meet us at
at the little falls bridge— After dinner, between five and six, we proceeded, taking the thill horse of my Son’s Gig, for our fourth in the Carriage— We came to little falls bridge soon after Sunset; and just after dark met the Hack which had come out from the city to meet us— The road from the Bridge to Georgetown is very bad—but we reached home safely, about nine in the Evening— Found Mr and Mrs Frye at the house—

I found a great accumulation of Letters, despatches, and business in the course of four days absence, which absorbed all my time— Mr Southard is engaged in making the arrangements necessary for despatching the Frigate Brandywine which is to be ready by the first week in September— She left the wharf where we had gone on board the 2d. instt. two days after and was lying at the mouth of the Eastern branch on Saturday as we were going to Loudoun— She is now nearly opposite Alexandria

The decision of the Court Martial upon Captain Porter was made this day, but was not transmitted to me. General Brown came and introduced to me Coll Thayer—Superintendent of the Military Academy at West-Point; and they both dined with us. General Jesup came to introduce Mr Nielson, who is from Kentucky— Mr Rush brought papers—recommendations for appointment of Lieutenants to the Revenue-Cutters, building at Baltimore— Dr Watkins and Dr Thornton came in the Evening— The multitude of my occupations and the intense heat of the weather leave me not a moment for writing in this Journal— While absent from the City on our excursion to Oakhill and Leesburg, I could not write, and now while retrieving that time the present day slips away to be recorded hereafter
12. V:30 symbols 30 symbols

Mr Southard brought me all the proceedings of the Court-Martial on the case of Captain Porter— And proposed that we should read them together— But the defence was incomplete— Walter Jones was his Counsel, and although the Court had directed that the defence should be delivered in writing, Jones had complied with this direction only in appearance, speaking as if from a written paper, but in reality expatiating from a brief— This defence was delivered last Friday and Saturday; and by the indulgence of the Court Jones was allowed till Monday, to produce it in writing— It was then not ready, and the Court adjourned from day to day that he might bring it in, till Wednesday—the Court then passed an order that if the defence should not be delivered the next morning they would make up their decision without it—of which they directed the judge Advocate to give notice to Captain Porter— The next day, that is yesterday a manuscript, purporting to be the defence upon the first charge was delivered in, with a promise that the rest should be furnished as soon as possible— The Court however made up their decision without waiting for it, and thus the papers were brought to me—with an additional manuscript of about half the defence on the second charge, which was delivered to the judge Advocate this morning; but had not been before the Court—and it was stated that the remainder would be ready in the course of this day. But Mr Southard said Mr Coxe, the judge Advocate had told him, that the manuscript differed materially from the defence as it was delivered in Court— I observed to Mr Southard that I could receive and act upon no paper, not transmitted to me by the Court itself
itself; and yet that it would be extremely irksome to me to decide upon the sentence of the Court, without that which the accused considered as his defence— I thought it best therefore, not to read any of the papers at present; but to send them back to the Court, together with that portion of the defence which had been delivered this morning to Mr Coxe, and with an intimation to the Court of my wish, that they would so far indulge the accused as to receive and transmit the remainder of his defence— Mr Southard prepared accordingly such a Letter, which after a slight revision was transmitted with the papers to the Court— Genl. Brown came concerning the proceedings of a Court of Inquiry in a case of Major A. Cumming of the 7th. Infantry; which I have not yet read— Burleigh and Wingate are about to return home to the State of Maine; apparently anxious for a decision upon the charges against Mark Langdon Hill— Burleigh, with Ezekiel Whitman and Ashur Ware, were commissioned to investigate those charges and have made a report with voluminous documents, also to be read before I can come to a final decision upon them. Hook Collector at Castine, is a witness on the Court Martial, upon Ramagewas an applicant for Office, and Van Zandt with some books published at New-York and sent me by the publishers— He has been also concerned in the recent publication of the life of Paul Jones—of which J. B. Colvin however is the author. Mr Graham left with me a report concerning the feud in the name of the President as Trustee for the Choctaw Indians; and also papers relating to complaints against George Davis a Surveyor of Lands in Mississippi and Louisiana. Mr Daniel Brent brought me despatches from several of our
Ministers abroad— Dr Watkins called in the Evening, with a pressing want of assistance which I was not able to give him.— Company to dine Evening billiards.
13. V:30. symbols 45 symbols 11. Clarke’s. N. Testt. Introdn.
General La Fayette with his family left us this day to go upon his farewell visit to the Ex-President’s Jefferson and Madison— General Brown called on him before his departure
Mr Graham had business from the Land-Office

Forsyth came to introduce Lewis who is the Collector at Mobile— Watkins came to tell me that he had succeeded in obtaining relief from his embarrassments— Pinkney is a Son of the late William Pinkney of Baltimore, who introduced himself, and made some peevish-remark, at his being summoned to attend here as a witness before the Court Martial, now sitting for the trial of several naval officers— He intimated that Baltimore was not respectfully treated because there were no great men there. A remark of which it seemed to me which was most conspicuous; its absurdity, or its impertinence. Dr Wallace informed me that the child at whose Christening we attended last Tuesday at Leesburg, and to whom General La Fayette stood Sponsor, died that same night—and such is human life— The child appeared at the ceremony to be in very good health— Mr Hopkinson and General Taylor, paid us Evening visits— They are here as Counsel to Captain Charles Stuart, who is to be tried by the Naval Court Martial now in Session, upon numerous charges relating to his conduct while Commander of our Squadron in the Pacific Ocean— The decision of the Court upon Captain Porter
was this day brought me by MrSouthard, together with the voluminous documents of the trial— The Court received the whole defence as finally delivered by his Counsel W. Jones. but remark that it differs materially from that which was orally pronounced before them. It contains particularly some severe insinuations and assertions against the judge Advocate Coxe, which the Court declare to be altogether unfounded— Mr Southard engaged to call to-morrow, to commence the reading of the Papers, which will take two or three days to get through—

Mr Dawson, General Brown’s Aid de Camp, came and informed me that Major Andrews had arrived from his Mission to Georgia, and to the Creek Indians, but immediately after his return, was seized with a fever so that he was unable to come out— I heard Mr Little in the Morning from 2. Corinthians 13.5 “Examine yourselves whether ye be in the faith; prove your own selves.

Know ye not your own selves, how that Jesus Christ is in you, except ye be reprobates?”— And in the afternoon, at Mr Baker’s from Revelations 1.5.6.— Unto him that loved us, and washed us from our sins in his own blood,—and hath made us kings and Priests unto God and his Father; to him be Glory and Dominion for ever and ever. Amen.” Mr Southard called upon me after the morning service; but I had read part of Captain Porters defence, which he had already perused, and I agreed to read the remainder of it by myself this day
16. V:30. symbols 30 symbols
Southard. S.N. Morning and Eve—concluded reading proceedings of Court-martial on Captain Porter—compared the citations from Adye, M’Arthur and Macomb on Courts-Martial—

Brown— Genl. with a plan of six acres of Land at Old Point Comfort, wanted for the School of Artillery practice to be rented for 3 years at 300 dollars a year— Brown’s remarks upon Mr Calhoun’s claiming the credit of new-organizing the War Department, and taking the Artillery School away from the command of the Major-General— Major Andrews ill since his return—to make his report in a few days— Gaines’s last Letter of to Govr. Troup; long. Brent. D. with Letter from Vaughan with copies of his credential Letter; and of S. Canning’s recall—
I desired Mr Brent to answer Mr Vaughan’s Letter.
Mention Mr Clay’s absence and say I would receive him next Saturday the 20th at One O’Clock, when he would introduce him.
Thornton— Dr. in the Evening; with his first Letter to Browne; which Mr Clay declined sending.
Oppressive heat continued last night and this day till eve.
Thunder-gust passed away South and west symbols
17. V. symbols 2 symbols 25 symbols
Clarke’s New Testament— Matthew 1.
The Night and Morning Cloudy— Heat abated Fahrenheit 84
Burke— Newspaper at Rockville

Southard S.N. with the Sentence of the Court-Martial, in the case of Captn. D. Porter, which I approved; according to the precedent in the case of Captain Barron— He read
also the proceedings of the Court on the trials of Lieutenants Whitlocke and Hunter which he is to approve.

Hay— George— He is here with Mrs Hay and Hortensia, going for her health to New-York and Saratoga— Spoke to him of the appointment of a judge for the Western district of Virginia— E. J. Duncan—some remarks concerning him. Hay said he was not much acquainted with that part of the State— Observations on the Ph. Doddrige— James Pindall and Allan Taylor.

Somerville. E. C.— wishes to go now for Sweden— Has much recovered from the rupture of a blood vessel; which has delayed for several weeks his departure— Offered a passage by Admiral Grivel of the French Squadron now at Norfolk.
Mr and Mrs Rush—Mr and Mrs and Miss Hay spent the Evening here
18. VI:30. Night cool— Great change of weather. Fahrenheit 70.
Matthew 2.
Brent— Daniel. Has notified Mr Vaughan that I will receive him next Saturday at 1 O’Clock.
Sullivan— George— came from Boston about a fortnight since. He dined with us.
An hour’s walk before dinner.
Burleigh. W. and
Wingate enquired if the case of M. L. Hill had been decided—not yet symbols
Charles’s Birthday 18.
19. V:30. Cool. Misty—Walk to the Post-Office.
Matthew 3—

Southard S.N—with a Letter from Captain D. Porter; asking leave of absence, during the term of his suspension which I told Mr Southard, I thought should be granted. Captain Morris to be asked if Mr Somerville can have a passage in the Brandywine— Shall Somerville’s destination be changed? Examination of recommendations for a Chaplain

Rush R. S.T—papers relating to G. Davis Surveyor of Land at Washington Mississippi— E. Gunning; Register of Land-Office, Sparta, Alabama, chosen a member of the Legislature of that State— Wishes a Sale of Land, advertised for a 2d. week in December, to be made a Month sooner; for his convenience— Not admissible— Conversation upon the deposits in the Banks— System to be revised— G. W. Owen’s Letter says Gunning informs him he has resigned— Clerks in the Treasury Department.
Jones’s remarks upon Gustavus Harrison
Rainy Evening— Wrote, half an hour—first of the Season symbols
20. VI. Walk an hour— Rainy Morning.
Matthew 4.
Smith Constantine—has not yet received his commission.

Vaughan— Charles Richard, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from Great-Britain. Presented by D. Brent, in the absence of the Secretary of State— Mr Vaughan delivered to me three Letters from the King of Great Britain—one the recal of Mr Stratford Canning—one his own credential Letter; and one the recredence of Mr Rush— He made a very short address on delivering them—which I answered.
Doyle— Mr— an attaché to the Legation, and
Sturt, Captain of the Phaeton frigate, which brought Mr Vaughan to Annapolis, were with him— Mr Vaughan presented Captain Sturt, and Mr Doyle to me.
Key— Francis B. about his project for a Fellenberg classical and agricultural School—asked the return of his pamphlet, which I could not find—

Somerville. W. C. going to Baltimore—I told him of my wish that he should go in the Brandywine frigate; and that I had spoken of it to Mr Southard. He will ask Captain Morris this Evening— He hopes the voyage will improve his health; but suffers excessively by Sea-sickness and wishes to consult Dr Physick.
21. V:30. Cool and Cloudy day. Matthew 5.
Heard Little. Proverbs 10.29—
Read Colman’s Sermon 23. (last.) on the doctrine of immortality.
Crucem Fer Animosé.
Heard O. B. Brown at Bakers—John 3.16.
Read Johnson—Sermon 17 upon Slander.
Received Letters from Govr Troup, denouncing Genl. Gaines.
Evening walk—Call at Mr Frye’s—who was not at home—
22. V:30. symbols 15 symbols 30 symbols Matthew 6.
Graham— George— About the papers relating to George Davis.

Surveyor General, on the Mississippi charges against him, and his jealousies and suspicions. I thought them erroneous, but not without much apparent cause— Graham thinks his temper very unfortunate— I spoke to Mr Graham of the Indian funds of which P.U.S. is trustee— And asked him to send me 1000 blank Land-grants
Kent—Dr Joseph—to recommend Benjamin Mead for keeper of a light house in Chesapeake Bay.

Pleasonton— Stephen 5th. Auditor—with him I examined the recommendations and applications for this appointment, about
twenty in number.— I directed the appointment of B. Mead—chiefly to avoid going out of the District— Examined also the recommendations of as many for a keeper of a Light-house at Owl’s Head, on Penobscot Bay in the State of Maine. I decided in favour of Isaac Stearns.

Brown— Genl— Spoke of the papers, proceedings of the Court of Inquiry on Major Cummings. I had not read them— Will come with T. P. Andrews to-morrow, to bring his Report on his special mission to Georgia.

Brent, Daniel—with Sundry despatches from the Dept. of State— Mr Clay arrived here last Evening, but is unwell, and has not been out this day. Saw in a newspaper the Account of his daughter’s death, only a few miles from hence— Letter from J. H. Pleasants at Liverpool— Letters from A. H. Everett and J. J. Appleton at Havre 14 & 15. July—and from R King Liverpool 30. June.
Hopkinson. Joseph— Lee. W. and Frye N. Evening Visitors.
Signed Virginia Military Land Warrants 3.
23. V. Walk an hour and a half.— no bath.
Matthew 7.
Graham George, with
Ross— Mr a native of France now settled in Louisiana—

Van de Venter, Major with a Letter from Govr Barbour, proposing the approval of offers to repair the broken bridges on the Cumberland Road; the contractors to wait for payment till an appropriation by Congress. I agreed to the approval.
Signed an order for the discharge of Elizabeth Walker from imprisonment at this City.

Southard S.N. with a Letter from Captain D. Porter asking for the publication in Force’s paper, of the finding of the Court of Inquiry, upon the charge against Porter relating to the carrying of Specie to which I consented— Instructions for Captain Morris to be prepared— Somerville, to go in the Brandywine— Papers relating to the resignation of Phillips as a Surgeon in the Navy— Notice respecting the restoration of Jacob Mull as a Sailing-Master
in the Navy.
Signed Commission of Samuel Blair, as member of the Legislative Council of Florida, in the place of Hernandez resigned.
Foster, Mr in behalf of J. H. Bennett the suspended consul at Pernambuco. To return about the end of the week.

Clay— Henry S.S. his daughter died two days after he left Lebanon— Conversation, upon public affairs— I gave Mr Clay Governor Troup’s last Letters and the other papers from Georgia, requesting him to read them and pass them to the other members of the Administration, for a subsequent consultation.
Genl. La Fayette the Frigate Brandywine W. C Somerville, Sweden and Greece— State of Kentucky—good principles prevailing there.

list.head: Major Andrews spoke generally of his transactions in Georgia, and mentioned the pecuniary speculations of Campbell the Commissioner of the U.S. upon the money to be paid to the emigrating Indians.

div.p: Andrews’s Report will be ready in two or three days.
Mary, Elizabeth and John, were at Captain Kuhn’s christening symbols
24. V:15. Walk to Georgetown. 1. hour. Matthew 8.

Elgar— Commr. of Public buildings—about warming the house in winter— Says it has been twice attempted by furnaces without success— Will write to N Biddle at my desire— Spoke of the works of Causici and Persico at the Capitol
Brent— Daniel, for the despatch from J. R. Poinsett, partly cyphered

Ingersoll. C. J. with his Son: a Midshipman in the Navy, going in the Brandywine— Brought a packet from Charleston S.C. for Genl. La Fayette— Ingersoll renewed also an application for a Midshipman’s warrant for a youth named Wilcox
Van de Venter— Major with a Letter from T. H. M’Kenney, asking funds to pay sums stipulated to Osage and Kanzas Indians.
Referred to the Secy. Treasy.
Evening symbols
25. V:15. Sun rose at 5. 25. symbols 30 symbols 40 symbols
Matthew 9.
Watkins— Dr. with an Article upon Porter’s trial. Some remarks upon it.
Brown— Genl.—to recommend Mrs. Brown’s brother Nathan Williams, as judge of the Western District of New-York.
Sent me afterwards a Letter from Mr Williams to him
Clarke— Robert: applies for the appointment of Justice of Peace in the 8th. Ward—with a recommendation and signatures, among which G. Higdan who resigns the same Office!

Clay— H. S.S. The Minister of the Netherlands Bangeman Huygens has arrived— Mr Clay receives him this day. I appointed to-morrow at one to receive him, with his Credential Letter—and 2. O’Clock for a meeting of the members of the Administration, upon Govr Troup’s last Letter, and denunciation of Genl. Gaines— I spoke of the appointment of District judges, in the Western Districts of Virginia and New-York— Also of that of a Collect at Bath in the District of Maine

list.head: Major comes from the Sault de St. Mary in the Michigan Territory where he has been in garrison.

div.p: Signed order for discharge of N. Hughes in prison here, for Petty Larceny.
order for allowance of payment by R. Rush of 1000 dollars to Alexr M’Rae— London.

Southard— S.N— Letter from Burleigh of what G. Sullivan told him that I should not decide on the case of M. L. Hill; till Congress meets— Frigate Brandywine will be ready by next
Tuesday— Papers in the case of Surgeon’s mate Phillips— symbols

Mr Allen the Clergyman of Baltimore came this Evening, and left a volume of Mrs Allen’s poems as a present for Mrs Adams— Mr and Mrs Rush visited here— And Genl La Fayette, his Son, Mr Le Vasseur and de Syon returned from Mr Monroe’s at Loudoun— They left his house this Morning— The General has visited Mr Jefferson, Mr. Madison and Govr Barbour.
Mr Jefferson’s health is on the decline— Thomas and Alexr. H. Hopkinson here also this Evening.
26. V. symbols 45 symbols Matthew 10 4 symbols

M’Lean Post master General— I had sent for him— Read to him the Letter from Baltimore, and enclosures, with charges against J. S. Skinner Post-master there— There has already been an enquiry, the result of which he will send me. He took the papers— I spoke to him of H. Lee, and the numerous complaints anonymous and otherwise against the employment of him in the Post-Office— Told him what I had heard—what I believed, and what I suspected—and that I traced all the anonymous Letters though apparently transmitted from Virginia, Albany N.Y. Alexandria, Tennessee &c to one and the same source— I thought a woman— Mr M Lean will enquire further— The Post-Office at New-York is not yet, but must soon be vacant— Difficulties about that appointment.
Graham— George—with a Report respecting the proceeds of Lands to be invested in name of P.U.S. for benefit of Choctaw Indians—proposes investment in U.S. 3 per Ct.

Bangeman— Huygens— Delivered his Credential Letter from the king of the Netherlands as his Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary—with a short address in French which I answered in the same language— He was introduced by H. Clay Secretary of State, and subsequently presented his Son, an officer of Artillery, but attached to the Legation.

Cabinet-Meeting at 2. present H. Clay S.S. R. Rush S.Tr and S. L. Southard S.N.— Questions— 1. whether any and if any what answer to be given to Govr Troup’s Letters of denunciation against Genl. Gaines and T. P. Andrews—and 2. whether any notice to be taken of Campbell. U.S. Commissioners avowal of pretensions to pecuniary profits from having the disbursement of monies for payment to Creek Indians— Much discussion upon the first point— Mr Clay thought no censure could with propriety be cast upon Genl. Gaines—That Troup’s Letters might be left without answer—or be briefly answered with great caution and delicacy— He thought this second alternative would be the best— And that it was important explicitly to deny that any Instructions had been given to any Officer of U.S. authorizing them to insult the Governor or authorities of Georgia— I doubted whether it would be possible to answer and deny injurious imputations with out entering upon useless and humiliating discussions in which even victory would be disgraceful— After much deliberation I conclude to draft a Letter from the Secretary of War, to Govr. Troup, answering his Letters to me; to be submitted at a meeting next Tuesday for consideration— The Report of Major T. P. Andrews was delivered to me, during the Meeting of this day by Major Van de Venter— Very Voluminous, and with many Documents. Custis. G. W. P. paid me a morning visit— Company to dine. Captain Allen of the Cadmus, who arrived this Morning. Mr Custis— Thomas and Alexander Hopkinson, Mr Kemper member of the Committee of Arrangements who had accompanied the Genl. here from Warrenton. Genl. La Fayette, his son George, Mr Le Vasseur, and de Syon— Mrs Adams was quite ill; confined the whole day to her bed with the rhumatism— Mr Clay declined dining with us, being not well, but came in the Evening, and spent an hour with us—
27. V.15 symbols 45 symbols 2 symbols Matthew—10.11.

M’Duel John a Lieutenant in one of the volunteer militia companies here, under sentence of Court-Martial, came in person to represent his grievances. I listened to him about an hour, reasoned with him a little, and referred him to the War Department.
Foster— Mr came about the papers concerning the case of James H. Bennett, consul at Pernambuco, which I had not read. I desired him to call again about the middle of next week.

Southard S.N. came with Captain Morris appointed to command the Frigate Brandywine— Brought also and shewed me the drafts of his Instructions to Morris—to Gregory who goes as first Lieutenant and to Rodgers— Genl. La Fayette is to be landed at Havre if practicable—then Morris leaves her, and is to visit the naval establishments in France and England, with a view to any improvements which may be introduced into our own; he is expected to return in six months— I made to him some observations, as to the course he should pursue in the Event, of any difficulty or obstruction to the landing of Genl. La Fayette occurring in France— I told him that as it was impossible to foresee specifically such an Event, I must barely give him a general caution to be prepared for it as probable: and that I should rely entirely upon his firmness and prudence to meet it— We spoke of a passage in the ship for W. C. Somerville; who after conversing with Morris thought that the attainable accommodations would not suit his state of health—he went to Philadelphia to consult Dr Physick and concluded to embark in a packet from New-York. I told Morris I had special reasons for wishing that Somerville, should go in the Frigate; and he said that good accommodation for him should be found or made— Mr Southard is to write to him at Philadelphia, and request him to come here—There was mention also of a Lieutenant de Bonneville, whom Genl. La Fayette had invited to go to France with him, before he expected to go in the Frigate: for whom he also obtained from General Brown a furlough of a year for that purpose; and who is now here; expecting to go with
with him— There is difficulty in providing accommodation for him— The General has not mentioned him and perhaps knows not that the young man does expect to go with him— I am to speak to the General concerning him.
Biddle— Captain James, came to take leave; being about to return to Philadelphia.

list.head:
Barton, is of the House of Porter,
Barton and of the earliest Settlers in the Western part of New-York; where they have now very large Establishments.

div.p: Signed Commission of Alfred Conkling as U.S. Judge for the Northern District of New-York.
Of Constantine Smith— 2d. Lieutenant in the Marine Corps.
The reading of T. P. Andrews’s Report occupied great part of the day— Weather still very warm.
Genl. La Fayette, and his family; and my Son John, dined at Mr M’Lean’s, the Postmaster General. symbols
Mrs Adams still confined mostly to bed with the rheumatic fever.
28. V:15— Sun rose 5:28. behind chimney Genl. Brown’s house.
symbols 45 symbols Matthew 12.
With Genl. La Fayette. Heard Little 1. Timothy 4.7.
The General thought his Sermon Ultra-Unitarian.
Read Johnson’s Sermon. 18 upon Fraud.

Conversation with Genl. La Fayette after Breakfast. I take every opportunity to dissuade him from having any participation in revolutionary projects in France— He says he will go quietly to La Grange— That he is 68 years old, and must leave revolutions to younger men— But there is fire beneath the cinders. Spoke to him of Somerville, and my intentions; upon which he said he would give up his own birth to him if necessary—of Bonneville—he did write him to go with him to France, thinking then to go on one of the Packets, and will be glad if he can be accommodated in the Ward room—
Heard a Stranger at Mr Baker’s from Matthew 16.26.
W. Lee here in the Evening— Mrs Adams yet ill
29. V:15. Sun rose 5. 29. symbols 45 symbols hours.
Blunt came for a subscription to the publication of two Charts, of the Northern, and Southern Ocean— I agreed, not to subscribe; but to take a copy of each of the charts.

Genl. Brown spoke to me concerning Lieutn Bonneville, and his expectation of going in the Brandywine frigate with Genl. La Fayette— Also of the appointment of Alfred Conkling as U.S. District Judge for the Northern District of New-York, which he approved— Major Van de Venter brought a Letter of 15. August from Governor Troup of Georgia, to the Secretary of War full as usual of “Guns, Drums, Trumpets, Blunderbuss and Thunder”—but declaring that he will not make the threatened survey of the Creek Indian Lands— Mr Southard came to recommend a Chaplain for the Frigate Brandywine— We fixed upon a Mr Ogilvie of New-York. Southard said he would speak to Captain Morris, that a passage may be secured to Lieutt. Bonneville; as of the Suite of Genl. La Fayette.

Genl. Hughes came with Mr Brent to take leave, being upon his return to New-Orleans— Mr Bakewell who came with Mr Baker had various important suggestions to make, one of which was the necessity of taking measures for abolishing the custom among the Choctaw Indians of destroying old women for witchcraft. He says that infanticide, which was very common has been put down and whipping a few of the culprits would suffice to put an end to the other detestable practice— Mr Bakewell promised to make communication upon this subject to the War Department. Genl Smith, and the Mayor, and President of the Common Council
of Georgetown, came with a view to making arrangements for joining in the procession to escort Genl. La Fayette to the Steamboat, the 7th. of next Month— Mr Young is a nephew of Mr Coxe— Mr Ringgold, for whom I had sent, came on the same object— General La Fayette, his Son, and Mr Le Vasseur left us this day to go on a visit to Woodlawn, and to Mount-Vernon—to return here to dinner, the day after to-morrow. Evening symbols
30. V:15— Sun-rose V:30. symbols

Sherburne brought a Manuscript Volume, containing the Journal of Paul Jones, in French, addressed in 1786 to Louis 16 King of France. He intends to publish an enlarged Edition of Jones’s Life in 2 Volumes—and made enquiries concerning the Portrait at the head of the Volume which is not a good likeness.

Browere, is a Sculptor who has made at New-York a Bust of Genl. La Fayette, and proposes to take Busts of all the Presidents— Major Van de Venter came for Instructions, concerning an answer to Genl. Gaines’s Letter of 4 Augt I gave him directions for the answer, a draft of which he afterwards brought and I approved— Cazenove came to introduce DuPont, of Wilmington Delaware— Mr Clay returned with his family to the City on Sunday Evening. I read to him the draft of a Letter to the Governor of Georgia, in reply to three from him— Clay spoke of a Conversation with Forsyth yesterday, who told him he thought the Surveyor of Georgia would be sent, and if taken up by Genl. Gaines he would be sued by the State Govt. in the Courts of the State. The cause would of course be transferred to the U.S. Courts, and so be judicially decided.

Mr Clay made some enquiries as to the final decision concerning J. Crowell; and said Forsyth had asserted a right on the part of Georgia to survey the Indian Lands, independent of the Treaty—of which he cited various precedents.

Mr Swann the District Attorney came to recommend Robert Page as Judge of the District Court U–S. for the Western District of Virginia—but Daniel Smith was already appointed— Swann is about to remove from Alexandria to this City—and says Judge Cranch will come also. symbols
31. V:15. Sun rose V:31. symbols 90 symbols

Foster came upon the business of Bennett, the ex-Consul at Pernambuco. I read Bennett’s papers while he was here— Except two in Portuguese, which are to be translated— I told Foster I should finally decide after comparing Bennett’s papers with those of Kirkpatrick— But said I saw not how Bennett could justify his requiring of Kirkpatrick proof that he was a Citizen U.S. before he would interpose to obtain his release from prison— N. Andrews is a chaplain in the U.S. Navy— Was a dissenting clergyman in England and came to this Country 30 years ago—with Dr. Priestley— Was with Captain Stewart in the Franklin, both in the Mediterranean and the Pacific— Now here as witness on Stewart’s trial— Called here—were on a visit—going to Baltimore— Dr Thornton called for his papers relating to his controversy with Mr Browne Secretary to the Franklin Society at Philadelphia— As to the right of every citizen to demand copies of all specifications at the Patent Office. He took them away—there is a legal opinion of H. Binney and John Sergeant in favour of the right— Thornton says Mr Wirt the Attorney General has given a written opinion against it; but it is not among these papers— General Macomb was here about
the levelling of the grounds at the Southern front of this house— He proposes to slope them in a glacis— Mr Southard came with several despatches from Commodore Rodgers, at Gibraltar—down to 7. July. Among the rest the correspondence with H. Nelson, who requested him to detach a frigate from his Squadron, to bring Heredia here as a Spanish Minister, with him— Felch the Chaplain has resigned. Genl. La Fayette returned from Woodlawn, and we had company to dinner— Messrs.Clay, Cazenove, Custis, DuPontRinggold and de Syon—with the General’s family and our own—15— A Mr Marks, an acquaintance of the General’s came in the Evening. Sultry day.

Day.— I have risen this Month, between 5 and 6 usually about a quarter of an hour before the Sun. Walk, bathe and swim—two hours—read an hour— Breakfast at 9— Visitors and business from ten till 5 in the afternoon— Dine— From six till dark at billiards and sometimes an hourly candle-light in the Evening— Retire to bed, from 9 to 10.
The month has been diversified by the visits of Genl. La Fayette and his family; and by mine with him to Mr Monroe, at Oakhill, and to Leesburg.
